articles.headline: Study Raises Questions on Coating of Aspirin
articles.snippet: The coating, meant to protect the stomach, interfered with the way the drug entered the body, arguing against the notion that some people are “aspirin resistant,” a study found.
articles.abstract: The coating, meant to protect the stomach, interfered with the way the drug entered the body, arguing against the notion that some people are “aspirin resistant,” a study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: While aspirin may prevent heart attacks and strokes, a commonly used coating to protect the stomach may obscure the benefits, leading doctors to prescribe more expensive prescription drugs, according to a study published Tuesday in the journal Circulation.

articles.headline: Unionizing the Bottom of the Pay Scale
articles.snippet: Labor unions in America are adopting unusual tactics, hoping to raise the floor for wages and working conditions in the ultracompetitive economy of the 21st century.
articles.abstract: Labor unions in America are adopting unusual tactics, hoping to raise the floor for wages and working conditions in the ultracompetitive economy of the 21st century.
articles.lead_paragraph: Other than poverty, José Carrillo and Joshua Williams have little in common. The austere life of Mr. Carrillo, a 79-year-old Peruvian immigrant from Washington Heights, is a universe apart from the hardscrabble reality of Mr. Williams, a 28-year-old single father from Atlanta staying at his aunt’s place in Brooklyn to save on rent.

articles.headline: To Stop Climate Change, Students Aim at College Portfolios
articles.snippet: Students are demanding that university endowment funds rid themselves of coal, oil and gas stocks in hopes of bringing climate change onto the national political agenda.
articles.abstract: Students are demanding that university endowment funds rid themselves of coal, oil and gas stocks in hopes of bringing climate change onto the national political agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: SWARTHMORE, Pa. — A group of Swarthmore College students is asking the school administration to take a seemingly simple step to combat pollution and climate change: sell off the endowment’s holdings in large fossil fuel companies. For months, they have been getting a simple answer: no.

articles.headline: In Tax Fight, G.O.P. Seeks a Position to Fall Back On
articles.snippet: With President Obama winning public support for higher tax rates on the rich, Congressional Republicans find themselves in a difficult political spot and are quietly beginning the search for a way out.
articles.abstract: With President Obama winning public support for higher tax rates on the rich, Congressional Republicans find themselves in a difficult political spot and are quietly beginning the search for a way out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With President Obama insisting on higher tax rates for affluent Americans and winning public support for the idea, Congressional Republicans find themselves in an increasingly difficult political spot and are quietly beginning to look for a way out.

articles.headline: Apps Redirect Text Messages, and Profits, From Cellular Providers
articles.snippet: Smartphone apps that use the Internet to send text messages are forcing wireless providers to change pricing models.
articles.abstract: Smartphone apps that use the Internet to send text messages are forcing wireless providers to change pricing models.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a long time, opening a cellphone bill was scary for the parents of teenagers. Charges for texting could reach hundreds of dollars a month, prompting many families to sign up for unlimited plans. But at perhaps $20 a month for each family member, that quickly added up, too.

articles.headline: Rhode Island Judge Has Stake in Pension Case Outcome
articles.snippet: The dispute is also being closely watched as a first major test of whether, and how, financially strained states and cities can cut the benefits of their workers and retirees.
articles.abstract: The dispute is also being closely watched as a first major test of whether, and how, financially strained states and cities can cut the benefits of their workers and retirees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can a judge rule impartially on pension cuts when her mother, her son, her uncle and even she herself all have a stake in preserving the status quo?

articles.headline: How Crash Cover-Up Altered China’s Succession
articles.snippet: The effort to suppress news of a deadly Ferrari crash, insiders  now reveal, hastened the decline of the departing president, Hu Jintao, and spurred the ascent of China’s new leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: The effort to suppress news of a deadly Ferrari crash, insiders  now reveal, hastened the decline of the departing president, Hu Jintao, and spurred the ascent of China’s new leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — “Thank you. I’m well. Don’t worry,” read the post on a Chinese social networking site. The brief comment, published in June, appeared to come from Ling Gu, the 23-year-old son of a high-powered aide to China’s president, and it helped quash reports that he had been killed in a Ferrari crash after a night of partying.

articles.headline: Citigroup to Cut 11,000 Jobs and Take $1 Billion Charge
articles.snippet: Citigroup announced on Wednesday that it would cut 11,000 jobs, reducing its work force by roughly 4 percent, as the bank moved to sharply reduce its expenses.
articles.abstract: Citigroup announced on Wednesday that it would cut 11,000 jobs, reducing its work force by roughly 4 percent, as the bank moved to sharply reduce its expenses.
